These observations of Jupiter’s auroras at a wavelength of 3.36 microns (F335M) were captured with Webb’s NIRCam (Near-Infrared Camera) on December 25, 2023. They also intend to follow up this research with more Webb observations, which they can compare with data from NASA’s Juno spacecraft to better explore the cause of the enigmatic bright emission. NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope has captured new details of the auroras on our solar system’s largest planet. Led by Jonathan Nichols at the University of Leicester in the UK, the research team discovered rapidly changing features in Jupiter’s auroras, revealing a level of activity that’s far more dynamic than scientists expected. Thanks to Webb’s incredible sensitivity, astronomers are now able to study these lights in greater detail to better understand Jupiter’s powerful magnetic environment. When these and other solar particles are swept up by Jupiter’s magnetic field, they’re accelerated to extreme speeds and collide with the planet’s atmosphere, creating bursts of glowing light. These glowing light shows are not only massive but also hundreds of times brighter than Earth’s auroras.
